title: Romans Chapter 11 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Romans chapter 11 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Romans Chapter 11 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Romans Chapter 11.

questions.question: According to Romans 11:1, what tribe was Paul from?
questions.correctAnswer: Benjamin
questions.explanation: Romans 11:1 states that Paul is of the tribe of Benjamin.

questions.question: Who made intercession to God against Israel as mentioned in Romans 11:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Elias
questions.explanation: Romans 11:2 says the scripture speaks of Elias making intercession to God against Israel.

questions.question: According to Romans 11:4, how many men did God reserve who have not bowed to Baal's image?
questions.correctAnswer: Seven thousand
questions.explanation: Romans 11:4 says God reserved seven thousand men who have not bowed the knee to the image of Baal.

questions.question: Romans 11:6 teaches that if grace is of works, then what is no more grace?
questions.correctAnswer: Grace
questions.explanation: Romans 11:6 explains that if grace is by works, then grace is no longer grace.

questions.question: What happened to the rest of Israel who did not obtain the election, according to Romans 11:7?
questions.correctAnswer: They were blinded
questions.explanation: Romans 11:7 states that the rest of Israel were blinded while the election obtained what they sought.

questions.question: What does Romans 11:9 say David called for their table to be?
options: A snare, a trap, and a stumblingblock
A feast, a blessing, and a refuge
A sword, a shield, and a crown
A river, a mountain, and a valley
questions.correctAnswer: A snare, a trap, and a stumblingblock
questions.explanation: Romans 11:9 records David saying let their table be a snare, a trap, and a stumblingblock.

questions.question: According to Romans 11:11, what has come to the Gentiles through Israel's fall?
questions.correctAnswer: Salvation
questions.explanation: Romans 11:11 says that through Israel's fall, salvation has come to the Gentiles.

questions.question: Who does Paul say he magnifies his office to in Romans 11:13?
questions.correctAnswer: The Gentiles
questions.explanation: Romans 11:13 shows Paul speaking to the Gentiles and magnifying his office as their apostle.

questions.question: What is described in Romans 11:16 as holy when the root is holy?
questions.correctAnswer: The branches
questions.explanation: Romans 11:16 says if the root is holy, so are the branches.

questions.question: Romans 11:20 warns believers not to be what because they stand by faith?
questions.correctAnswer: Highminded
questions.explanation: Romans 11:20 instructs believers not to be highminded but to fear.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 11:22 states that God shows severity to those who fell and goodness to those who continue in His goodness.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Romans 11:22 explains the goodness and severity of God toward different groups based on their actions.

questions.question: True or False: According to Romans 11:23, those who abide not in unbelief shall be graffed in again by God.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Romans 11:23 says God is able to graff those who do not remain in unbelief back into the olive tree.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 11:26 says all Israel shall be saved when the Deliverer comes out of Sion.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Romans 11:26 states that all Israel shall be saved according to the scripture about the Deliverer.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Romans 11:29: 'For the gifts and calling of God are without ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: repentance
questions.explanation: Romans 11:29 states that the gifts and calling of God are without repentance.

questions.question: According to Romans 11:36, to whom belongs all things?
options: Him who is of, through, and to him
questions.correctAnswer: Him who is of, through, and to him
questions.explanation: Romans 11:36 says all things are of him, through him, and to him.

medium.title: Romans Chapter 11 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Romans Chapter 11 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is discouraged, feeling that God has abandoned His people. Based on Romans 11, what biblical truth would you share about God's faithfulness?
options: God has not cast away His people and remains faithful to those He foreknew
God has completely abandoned His people due to their sins
God only cares for Gentiles now and has rejected Israel
God’s promises are conditional on perfect obedience
questions.correctAnswer: God has not cast away His people and remains faithful to those He foreknew
questions.explanation: Romans 11:1-2 clearly states that God has not cast away His people who He foreknew. This passage reassures believers of God’s enduring faithfulness despite appearances.

questions.question: How does Romans 11 teach us about humility in the Christian walk when considering the relationship between Jews and Gentiles?
options: Do not boast against the branches for the root supports you
Boast in your own achievements over others
Ignore the heritage of others since you are grafted in
Claim superiority because you were grafted in
questions.correctAnswer: Do not boast against the branches for the root supports you
questions.explanation: Romans 11:18 emphasizes humility by instructing believers not to boast against the natural branches since the root supports the branches, illustrating dependence on God's grace.

questions.question: A believer struggles with feeling excluded from God’s blessings because of past failures. What encouragement does Romans 11 offer about God's ability to restore?
options: God is able to graft in again those who do not remain in unbelief
Once cut off, there is no hope for restoration
Only natural branches can receive blessings
Restoration depends on human effort alone
questions.correctAnswer: God is able to graft in again those who do not remain in unbelief
questions.explanation: Romans 11:23 teaches that God can graft back in those who repent from unbelief, highlighting His mercy and readiness to restore.

questions.question: How does Romans 11 instruct believers to view their spiritual standing in relation to others?
options: Stand by faith humbly, fearing God and not being arrogant
Be proud because you replaced others
Ignore warnings about unbelief since faith guarantees safety
Boast in your own wisdom and strength
questions.correctAnswer: Stand by faith humbly, fearing God and not being arrogant
questions.explanation: Romans 11:20-21 warns believers not to be highminded but to stand by faith with reverence, recognizing God’s judgment and mercy.

questions.question: What practical lesson about prayer and intercession can we learn from the example of Elijah in Romans 11?
options: Persist in interceding for others even when it seems you are alone
Stop praying when you feel isolated
Intercession is only for personal needs
Prayer is unnecessary if you feel abandoned
questions.correctAnswer: Persist in interceding for others even when it seems you are alone
questions.explanation: Romans 11:2-3 shows Elijah interceding for Israel despite feeling alone, teaching perseverance in prayer and concern for others.

questions.question: According to Romans 11, how should believers respond when others stumble in faith?
options: God uses their fall to bring salvation to others and provoke them to jealousy
They have permanently fallen and cannot be restored
Ignore their failure and focus only on yourself
Judge them harshly for their mistakes
questions.correctAnswer: God uses their fall to bring salvation to others and provoke them to jealousy
questions.explanation: Romans 11:11 explains that others’ stumbling is part of God’s plan to bring salvation to the Gentiles and to provoke Israel to jealousy, showing God’s sovereignty.

questions.question: How does the passage in Romans 11 encourage generosity and stewardship concerning God's riches?
options: God’s riches increase when one group falls and another is blessed, encouraging sharing of blessings
Material wealth is the only sign of God’s favor
Keep blessings for yourself to ensure security
God’s blessings are limited and should be hoarded
questions.correctAnswer: God’s riches increase when one group falls and another is blessed, encouraging sharing of blessings
questions.explanation: Romans 11:12 shows that the fall of some is the riches of the world, and the diminishing of others is the riches of the Gentiles, encouraging believers to see blessings as part of God’s greater plan and stewardship.

questions.question: A believer feels tempted to pride because of their faith. What biblical truth from Romans 11 can help them maintain humility?
options: You do not bear the root, but the root bears you
Faith is earned by human effort
You are superior because you were grafted in
Unbelief is less serious than faith
questions.correctAnswer: You do not bear the root, but the root bears you
questions.explanation: Romans 11:18 teaches humility by reminding believers that their spiritual life depends on God (the root), not on their own merit.

questions.question: According to Romans 11, what is the relationship between grace and works in salvation?
options: If salvation is by grace, it is not by works; otherwise grace is no longer grace
Salvation is earned by good works alone
Grace and works have equal roles in salvation
Works can replace grace in the Christian life
questions.correctAnswer: If salvation is by grace, it is not by works; otherwise grace is no longer grace
questions.explanation: Romans 11:6 clarifies that salvation is by grace and not by works, emphasizing the unmerited favor of God.

questions.question: What does Romans 11 teach about perseverance through trials and remaining in God’s goodness?
options: Continue in God’s goodness or you also will be cut off
Trials mean God has rejected you permanently
God’s goodness is unconditional regardless of faithfulness
questions.correctAnswer: Continue in God’s goodness or you also will be cut off
questions.explanation: Romans 11:22 warns believers about the severity of God if they do not continue in His goodness, encouraging perseverance in faith.

questions.question: A believer wants to understand how God’s plan includes both Jews and Gentiles. What does Romans 11 reveal about this?
options: Blindness has happened in part to Israel until the full number of Gentiles has come in
God has rejected Israel completely in favor of Gentiles
Gentiles replace Israel permanently in God’s plan
Israel and Gentiles are separate with no connection in salvation
questions.correctAnswer: Blindness has happened in part to Israel until the full number of Gentiles has come in
questions.explanation: Romans 11:25 explains the mystery of partial blindness to Israel until the fullness of Gentiles comes in, showing God’s inclusive plan.

questions.question: How can Romans 11 inspire believers in evangelism and sharing the Gospel with others?
options: Through outreach to the Gentiles, some of Israel may be saved
Only Israel should receive the Gospel
Sharing the Gospel has no effect on others’ salvation
questions.correctAnswer: Through outreach to the Gentiles, some of Israel may be saved
questions.explanation: Romans 11:14 shows Paul’s desire to provoke Israel to emulation through Gentile evangelism, encouraging believers to share the Gospel.

questions.question: True or False: According to Romans 11, God's gifts and calling are subject to change and repentance.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Romans 11:29 states that the gifts and calling of God are without repentance, meaning they are steadfast and unchanging.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 11 teaches that all things come from God, are sustained by God, and exist for His glory.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Romans 11:36 declares that all things are from Him, through Him, and to Him, emphasizing God's sovereignty and glory in all.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Romans 11 describes a remnant according to the election of ______.
questions.correctAnswer: grace
questions.explanation: Romans 11:5 refers to a present remnant according to the election of grace, highlighting God's unmerited favor.

hard.title: Romans Chapter 11 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Romans Chapter 11.

questions.question: In Romans 11:4, how many men did God reserve who had not bowed the knee to the image of Baal, and what is the significance of this number in the context of divine election?
questions.correctAnswer: Seven thousand
questions.explanation: Romans 11:4 states that God reserved seven thousand men who had not bowed to Baal, illustrating God's preservation of a faithful remnant, a concept rooted in Old Testament prophetic traditions emphasizing divine election and mercy.

questions.question: What theological principle does Paul emphasize in Romans 11:6 regarding grace and works?
options: Grace cannot be earned by works
Works are the basis of salvation
Grace and works are equally necessary
Works nullify the need for grace
questions.correctAnswer: Grace cannot be earned by works
questions.explanation: Romans 11:6 explains that if salvation is by grace, it is not by works, otherwise grace would no longer be grace, highlighting the doctrine of salvation by grace alone.

questions.question: According to Romans 11:7, what happened to the majority of Israel in relation to their spiritual seeking?
questions.correctAnswer: They were blinded
questions.explanation: Romans 11:7 states that while the elect obtained what they sought, the rest of Israel were blinded, indicating a partial hardening in response to unbelief.

questions.question: Which Old Testament figure does Paul reference in Romans 11:2-3 to illustrate God's preservation of a faithful remnant?
questions.correctAnswer: Elias (Elijah)
questions.explanation: Romans 11:2-3 references Elijah's intercession against Israel, showing God's ongoing preservation of a faithful remnant despite widespread apostasy.

questions.question: What does Paul mean in Romans 11:11 when he says, 'Have they stumbled that they should fall?' and what is the outcome of this stumbling?
options: No; their fall brings salvation to the Gentiles
No; their fall is temporary and irrelevant
Yes; it causes God's judgment to cease
questions.correctAnswer: No; their fall brings salvation to the Gentiles
questions.explanation: Romans 11:11 explains that Israel's stumbling is not a total fall but serves to bring salvation to the Gentiles, showing God's redemptive plan through apparent judgment.

questions.question: How does Paul use the metaphor of the olive tree in Romans 11:17-18 to describe the relationship between Gentile believers and Israel?
options: Gentiles are wild olive branches grafted into the cultivated olive tree
Israel is a wild olive tree among cultivated Gentiles
Both Israel and Gentiles are wild olive trees
Gentiles are broken branches removed from the tree
questions.correctAnswer: Gentiles are wild olive branches grafted into the cultivated olive tree
questions.explanation: Romans 11:17-18 uses the olive tree metaphor where Gentiles are wild olive branches grafted into the cultivated tree, symbolizing inclusion into God's covenant people.

questions.question: What warning does Paul give in Romans 11:20-21 to Gentile believers regarding their position in God's olive tree?
options: Do not be arrogant but fear, as God can also cut you off
Boast in your grafting and superiority
Ignore the natural branches as irrelevant
God will always keep you regardless of faith
questions.correctAnswer: Do not be arrogant but fear, as God can also cut you off
questions.explanation: Romans 11:20-21 warns Gentiles not to be arrogant about their inclusion, reminding them that God did not spare the natural branches and can cut off grafted branches if they fall into unbelief.

questions.question: In Romans 11:25, what 'mystery' does Paul reveal concerning Israel and the Gentiles?
options: Partial blindness has happened to Israel until the fullness of the Gentiles comes in
Israel has been completely rejected forever
Gentiles will never be fully included
questions.correctAnswer: Partial blindness has happened to Israel until the fullness of the Gentiles comes in
questions.explanation: Romans 11:25 reveals the mystery that Israel's partial spiritual blindness is temporary until the full number of Gentiles is included, showing God's unfolding plan of salvation.

questions.question: According to Romans 11:26, what will happen to 'all Israel' and how is this connected to Old Testament prophecy?
options: All Israel shall be saved, as prophesied that the Deliverer will come out of Zion
All Israel will be condemned for unbelief
Only the Gentiles will be saved
Israel will be replaced by the church
questions.correctAnswer: All Israel shall be saved, as prophesied that the Deliverer will come out of Zion
questions.explanation: Romans 11:26 affirms that all Israel will be saved, citing prophecy that the Deliverer will come from Zion to turn away ungodliness from Jacob, linking to Isaiah and other prophetic texts.

questions.question: What does Paul mean by 'gifts and calling of God are without repentance' in Romans 11:29, and how does this relate to God's covenant faithfulness?
options: God does not revoke His gifts or calling despite human unfaithfulness
God frequently changes His promises based on circumstances
Human effort can override God's calling
The gifts are conditional on perfect obedience
questions.correctAnswer: God does not revoke His gifts or calling despite human unfaithfulness
questions.explanation: Romans 11:29 emphasizes God's unchanging nature and covenant faithfulness, showing that His gifts and calling to Israel remain irrevocable despite their unbelief.

questions.question: How does Romans 11:32 explain God's purpose in allowing unbelief among all people?
options: To end the covenant with Israel
questions.correctAnswer: To have mercy upon all
questions.explanation: Romans 11:32 states that God has included all in unbelief so that He might extend mercy to all, highlighting the universal scope of divine mercy.

questions.question: Which Psalm is alluded to in Romans 11:9-10 regarding the spiritual blindness and judgment on Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Psalm 69
questions.explanation: Romans 11:9-10 quotes Psalm 69, which speaks of the table becoming a snare and their eyes being darkened, emphasizing divine judgment on Israel's unbelief.

questions.question: True or False: According to Romans 11:13-14, Paul seeks to provoke Gentiles to jealousy in order to save some of his fellow Israelites.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Romans 11:13-14 shows Paul's apostolic mission to Gentiles is also aimed at provoking Israel to emulation and salvation.

questions.question: What is the ultimate doxology that concludes Romans 11:36, and how does it summarize the theological message of the chapter?
options: For of Him, and through Him, and to Him are all things; to whom be glory forever
Praise the Lord, for He is good
Glory belongs to the church on earth
The kingdom belongs to the Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: For of Him, and through Him, and to Him are all things; to whom be glory forever
questions.explanation: Romans 11:36 concludes with a doxology affirming God's sovereignty over all creation, encapsulating the chapter's theme of God's wise and merciful plan for Jews and Gentiles alike.

questions.question: How does Romans 11:16 use the concept of 'firstfruits' and 'root' to develop the typology of holiness linking Israel and the church?
options: If the firstfruit is holy, so is the lump; if the root is holy, so are the branches
Only the firstfruit is holy, the rest are common
The root is holy, but the branches are separate
The firstfruit and root are unrelated
questions.correctAnswer: If the firstfruit is holy, so is the lump; if the root is holy, so are the branches
questions.explanation: Romans 11:16 employs agricultural typology to show that the holiness of Israel (firstfruit and root) extends to the whole people, including Gentile believers grafted into the covenant.

theological.title: Romans Chapter 11 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Romans Chapter 11 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Romans 11:1, how does Paul identify himself in relation to Israel?
options: An Israelite, of the seed of Abraham, of the tribe of Benjamin
A Gentile called to the Jews
A Levite dedicated to the temple
questions.correctAnswer: An Israelite, of the seed of Abraham, of the tribe of Benjamin
questions.explanation: Romans 11:1 shows Paul affirming his identity as an Israelite, descended from Abraham and specifically from the tribe of Benjamin, emphasizing God's faithfulness to His chosen people. This is consistent with Genesis 49:27, Philippians 3:5, and Acts 22:3 which affirm Paul's Jewish heritage, and also with God's promise to Abraham and his seed (Genesis 12:3; Galatians 3:16).

questions.question: What does God say in Romans 11:4 about the number of people who did not bow to Baal?
options: Seven thousand men were reserved who did not bow the knee to the image of Baal
The entire nation bowed to Baal
questions.correctAnswer: Seven thousand men were reserved who did not bow the knee to the image of Baal
questions.explanation: Romans 11:4 references God's answer to Elijah, stating that seven thousand men were preserved who did not worship Baal. This highlights God's sovereign preservation of a faithful remnant, consistent with Old Testament examples of God's protection of a remnant (Isaiah 10:20-22; 1 Kings 19:18).

questions.question: What is the nature of salvation according to Romans 11:6?
options: Salvation is by grace and not by works
Salvation is by keeping the law
questions.correctAnswer: Salvation is by grace and not by works
questions.explanation: Romans 11:6 explains that if salvation is by grace, it is not by works, because grace would no longer be grace. This aligns with Ephesians 2:8-9 and Titus 3:5, which affirm salvation as a gift of grace, not human merit, consistent with the doctrine of justification by faith.

questions.question: What has happened to the rest of Israel who did not obtain what they sought, according to Romans 11:7?
questions.correctAnswer: They were blinded
questions.explanation: Romans 11:7 states that while the elect obtained what they sought, the rest of Israel were blinded. This blindness is related to God's sovereign judgment and is supported by Isaiah 6:9-10 and Deuteronomy 29:4, showing a partial hardening for a divine purpose (cf. John 12:40).

questions.question: What Old Testament figure is quoted in Romans 11:9 to describe the spiritual condition of the disobedient?
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: Romans 11:9 quotes David, illustrating the spiritual snare and stumbling block set for the disobedient. This reference connects New Testament teaching with Psalms 69:22-23 where David expresses lament over enemies, highlighting the continuity of God's word across Scripture.

questions.question: According to Romans 11:11, what was the purpose of Israel's fall?
options: Salvation has come to the Gentiles to provoke Israel to jealousy
Israel's fall was permanent and final
Israel's fall was due to God's rejection
questions.correctAnswer: Salvation has come to the Gentiles to provoke Israel to jealousy
questions.explanation: Romans 11:11 teaches that Israel's stumble was not to cause permanent downfall but to bring salvation to the Gentiles, with the purpose of provoking Israel to jealousy. This reflects God's redemptive plan including all nations, resonating with passages like Isaiah 49:6 and Deuteronomy 32:21.

questions.question: What analogy does Paul use in Romans 11:17 to describe Gentile believers grafted into God's people?
options: Wild olive tree branches grafted into the good olive tree
Vine branches grafted into a fig tree
questions.correctAnswer: Wild olive tree branches grafted into the good olive tree
questions.explanation: Romans 11:17 uses the metaphor of a wild olive branch grafted into a cultivated olive tree to illustrate Gentile inclusion into the people of God. This imagery emphasizes unity and continuity in God's covenant, consistent with Jeremiah 11:16 and Psalm 80:8-9.

questions.question: What warning does Paul give in Romans 11:20 to those grafted in by faith?
options: Do not be arrogant, but fear, because they were broken off due to unbelief
questions.correctAnswer: Do not be arrogant, but fear, because they were broken off due to unbelief
questions.explanation: Romans 11:20 warns grafted-in believers not to be arrogant but to fear, as the natural branches were broken off due to unbelief. This teaching calls for humility and vigilance, echoing Deuteronomy 8:11-14 and Proverbs 16:18 about pride and falling.

questions.question: According to Romans 11:23, what is God's ability regarding the natural branches that were broken off?
options: God is able to graft them in again if they do not remain in unbelief
questions.correctAnswer: God is able to graft them in again if they do not remain in unbelief
questions.explanation: Romans 11:23 affirms God's power to restore the natural branches if they abandon unbelief. This restoration highlights God's mercy and faithfulness, consistent with Ezekiel 37:21-22 and Jeremiah 31:33-34 regarding Israel's future repentance and restoration.

questions.question: What mystery does Paul reveal in Romans 11:25 concerning Israel and the Gentiles?
options: Partial blindness has come to Israel until the full number of Gentiles is reached
Israel has been completely rejected forever
Gentiles will never be included in God's plan
Israel's blindness is permanent and unchangeable
questions.correctAnswer: Partial blindness has come to Israel until the full number of Gentiles is reached
questions.explanation: Romans 11:25 unveils the mystery that Israel's blindness is partial and temporary, lasting until the fullness of the Gentiles has come in. This fits the biblical narrative of God's plan unfolding progressively (Isaiah 59:20-21; Jeremiah 31:31-34; Hosea 1:10).

questions.question: What is the ultimate outcome for all Israel according to Romans 11:26?
options: All Israel shall be saved, as the Deliverer comes out of Zion
Israel will remain in unbelief forever
Only a few Israelites will be saved
questions.correctAnswer: All Israel shall be saved, as the Deliverer comes out of Zion
questions.explanation: Romans 11:26 promises that all Israel will be saved when the Deliverer comes from Zion and turns away ungodliness from Jacob. This is consistent with Old Testament prophecies (Isaiah 59:20; Jeremiah 31:34) and New Testament fulfillment in Christ's redemptive work.

questions.question: What does Romans 11:29 say about the gifts and calling of God?
questions.correctAnswer: They are without repentance
questions.explanation: Romans 11:29 teaches that God's gifts and calling are irrevocable and unchangeable. This emphasizes God's faithfulness and sovereignty, echoing Jeremiah 31:3 and 2 Timothy 1:9 where God's promises and calling are steadfast.

questions.question: How does Romans 11:32 summarize God's purpose in concluding all in unbelief?
options: That He might have mercy upon all
That He might show no mercy
That He might exclude some forever
questions.correctAnswer: That He might have mercy upon all
questions.explanation: Romans 11:32 states that God has allowed all to be under unbelief so that He may extend mercy to all, reflecting the universal scope of God's redemptive plan. This accords with Ezekiel 18:23 and 2 Peter 3:9 which affirm God's desire for all to repent and be saved.

questions.question: What attribute of God is highlighted in Romans 11:33?
options: The depth of His wisdom and knowledge, unsearchable judgments
questions.correctAnswer: The depth of His wisdom and knowledge, unsearchable judgments
questions.explanation: Romans 11:33 praises the infinite wisdom and knowledge of God and the inscrutability of His judgments, underscoring divine sovereignty. This aligns with Job 11:7-8, Isaiah 55:8-9, and Psalm 147:5 about God's incomprehensible ways.

questions.question: According to Romans 11:36, to whom belongs all glory forever?
options: To God, of whom, through whom, and to whom are all things
questions.correctAnswer: To God, of whom, through whom, and to whom are all things
questions.explanation: Romans 11:36 concludes that all things originate from God, are sustained through Him, and exist for His glory forever. This doxology reflects the comprehensive sovereignty of God, consistent with 1 Corinthians 8:6 and Colossians 1:16-17.
